pageProps.contentHtml:
Midterm 1

This page will only include solutions to Problems 1 and 4, which were the ones I graded. The professor will provide solutions for Problems 2 and 3 elsewhere.

The solutions I write down here would receive full points from me. They aren't the only solutions that can receive full points, of course.

Table of Contents

  • Problem 1

  • Problem 4

    • Solution 1 (using open covers)
    • Solution 2 (using sequences)

Problem 1

Let (X,d)\p{X, d}(X,d) be a metric space, and let E,FE, FE,F be open subsets of XXX. Suppose E∩F≠∅E \cap F \neq \emptysetE∩F=∅ and E∩∂F≠∅E \cap \partial F \neq \emptysetE∩∂F=∅. For any x∈E∩∂Fx \in E \cap \partial Fx∈E∩∂F, show that x∈E∩F‾x \in \cl{E \cap F}x∈E∩F. (Hint: you can use the fact that for any x∈Xx \in Xx∈X, x∈E∩F‾x \in \cl{E \cap F}x∈E∩F if and only if for all r>0r > 0r>0, B(x,r)∩(E∩F)≠∅B\p{x, r} \cap \p{E \cap F} \neq \emptysetB(x,r)∩(E∩F)=∅.)

Solution.

Fix x∈E∩∂Fx \in E \cap \partial Fx∈E∩∂F. Since x∈Ex \in Ex∈E and EEE is open, there exists r0>0r_0 > 0r0​>0 such that B(x0,r)⊆EB\p{x_0, r} \subseteq EB(x0​,r)⊆E.

Now let r>0r > 0r>0. There are two cases: r≤r0r \leq r_0r≤r0​ and r>r0r > r_0r>r0​.

Case 1: r≤r0r \leq r_0r≤r0​

In this case, B(x,r)⊆B(x,r0)⊆EB\p{x, r} \subseteq B\p{x, r_0} \subseteq EB(x,r)⊆B(x,r0​)⊆E. Moreover, because x∈∂Fx \in \partial Fx∈∂F, we have B(x,r)∩F≠∅B\p{x, r} \cap F \neq \emptysetB(x,r)∩F=∅. Thus

∅≠B(x,r)∩F=B(x,r0)∩E∩F\emptyset \neq B\p{x, r} \cap F = B\p{x, r_0} \cap E \cap F∅=B(x,r)∩F=B(x,r0​)∩E∩F

in this case.

Case 2: r>r0r > r_0r>r0​

Here, we have instead B(x,r0)⊆B(x,r)B\p{x, r_0} \subseteq B\p{x, r}B(x,r0​)⊆B(x,r). As above, we have

∅≠B(x,r0)∩F(x∈∂F)=B(x,r0)∩E∩F(B(x,r0)⊆E)⊆B(x,r)∩E∩F,(r0<r)\begin{aligned} \emptyset &\neq B\p{x, r_0} \cap F &&\p{x \in \partial F} \\ &= B\p{x, r_0} \cap E \cap F && \p{B\p{x, r_0} \subseteq E} \\ &\subseteq B\p{x, r} \cap E \cap F, && \p{r_0 < r} \end{aligned}∅​=B(x,r0​)∩F=B(x,r0​)∩E∩F⊆B(x,r)∩E∩F,​​(x∈∂F)(B(x,r0​)⊆E)(r0​<r)​

so B(x,r0)∩E∩F≠∅B\p{x, r_0} \cap E \cap F \neq \emptysetB(x,r0​)∩E∩F=∅ in this case also.

In all cases, we have shown B(x,r0)∩E∩F≠∅B\p{x, r_0} \cap E \cap F \neq \emptysetB(x,r0​)∩E∩F=∅, so xxx is an adherent point of E∩FE \cap FE∩F.

Problem 4

Let f ⁣:X→Y\func{f}{X}{Y}f:X→Y be a continuous map from one metric space (X,dX)\p{X, d_X}(X,dX​) to another (Y,dY)\p{Y, d_Y}(Y,dY​). Let K⊆XK \subseteq XK⊆X be any compact subset of XXX. Prove that the image f(K)≔{f(x)∣x∈K}f\p{K} \coloneqq \set{f\p{x} \mid x \in K}f(K):={f(x)∣x∈K} of YYY is also compact.

Solution.

Solution 1 (using open covers)

Let {Uα}α∈I\set{U_\alpha}_{\alpha \in I}{Uα​}α∈I​ be an open cover of f(K)f\p{K}f(K). Since fff is continuous, f−1(Uα)f^{-1}\p{U_\alpha}f−1(Uα​) is open in XXX for any α∈I\alpha \in Iα∈I. Moreover,

K⊆f−1(f(K))⊆f−1(⋃α∈IUα)=⋃α∈If−1(Uα)\begin{aligned} K \subseteq f^{-1}\p{f\p{K}} \subseteq f^{-1}\p{\bigcup_{\alpha \in I} U_{\alpha}} = \bigcup_{\alpha \in I} f^{-1}\p{U_{\alpha}} \end{aligned}K⊆f−1(f(K))⊆f−1(α∈I⋃​Uα​)=α∈I⋃​f−1(Uα​)​

In other words, {f−1(Uα)}α∈I\set{f^{-1}\p{U_\alpha}}_{\alpha \in I}{f−1(Uα​)}α∈I​ is an open cover of KKK, so since KKK is compact, there exist α1,…,αn∈I\alpha_1, \ldots, \alpha_n \in Iα1​,…,αn​∈I such that {f−1(Uα1),…,f−1(Uαn)}\set{f^{-1}\p{U_{\alpha_1}}, \ldots, f^{-1}\p{U_{\alpha_n}}}{f−1(Uα1​​),…,f−1(Uαn​​)} is a finite subcover of KKK. Finally,

f(K)⊆f(⋃i=1nf−1(Uαi))⊆⋃i=1nUαi,f\p{K} \subseteq f\p{\bigcup_{i=1}^n f^{-1}\p{U_{\alpha_i}}} \subseteq \bigcup_{i=1}^n U_{\alpha_i},f(K)⊆f(i=1⋃n​f−1(Uαi​​))⊆i=1⋃n​Uαi​​,

so {Uα1,…,Uαn}\set{U_{\alpha_1}, \ldots, U_{\alpha_n}}{Uα1​​,…,Uαn​​} is a finite subcover of f(K)f\p{K}f(K).

Solution 2 (using sequences)

Let (yn)n⊆f(K)\p{y_n}_n \subseteq f\p{K}(yn​)n​⊆f(K) be an arbitrary sequence. By definition, for each n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N, there exists xn∈Kx_n \in Kxn​∈K such that yn=f(xn)y_n = f\p{x_n}yn​=f(xn​). Since KKK is compact, there exists a subsequence (xnk)k\p{x_{n_k}}_k(xnk​​)k​ which converges to some x0∈Kx_0 \in Kx0​∈K. By continuity of fff,

lim⁡k→∞ynk=lim⁡k→∞f(xnk)=f(x0)∈f(K),\lim_{k\to\infty} y_{n_k} = \lim_{k\to\infty} f\p{x_{n_k}} = f\p{x_0} \in f\p{K},k→∞lim​ynk​​=k→∞lim​f(xnk​​)=f(x0​)∈f(K),

which shows that (ynk)k\p{y_{n_k}}_k(ynk​​)k​ is a convergent subsequence of (yn)n\p{y_n}_n(yn​)n​. Thus, f(K)f\p{K}f(K) is compact.
